root: ^The store was still lit like the area outside, but you can’t see or hear anyone.

^The scale of the convenience store is both impressive and puzzling, considering its localized entirely within a circus tent. Just goes to show the popularity of clowning, that it can justify a space like this.
^Though it feels absurd, taking in the rows of products. They really did just place a whole convenience store in here.

^It has everything you’d expect. Trusty snacks, rows of energy drinks… Even items like cleaning supplies, matches and… kitchen knives? When would anybody have use for all of this during a performance?
^Lost in thought, you inspect some cheaply made beauty products by the register. Your browsing was sharply interrupted by a shrill shriek.

^Oh, shit, I mean- uh, hi, welcome to Under lOOO, where everything costs Under lOOO! How can I help, beloved customer? …Wait, is it “dear customer?” “Valued customer?” Oh god, I thought we were closed for the public I’m too tired for this.
^The uniformed clown’s voice was shaky, making her introduction sound more like a plea than a welcome.
^Don’t worry, I’m not buying anything. You’re closed, after all.
^She sighed in relief, though her shoulders remained tense.
^Thank god. I thought I was sleeping on the job for a second. Wait, if we’re closed, how’d you get in…?
^You nod, and she slumps into the chair behind the register.
^You scared me, but at least I’m awake again. There’s always work left to do, I shouldn’t have gone to bed anyway.
^She points to some shelves behind the register.
^You didn’t notice before, but there’s a wrinkled, horrifically blue Under 1000 branded sleeping bag underneath.
^A single stuffed animal, looking to be some kind of pop culture character, is carrying the burden of giving the space a single twinge of homeliness.
^You actually have no idea what to say. Somehow, she’d made a mattress on the floor seem like peak comfort.
^It’s not that bad once you get used to it.
^…No, you’re right. It is still that bad once you get used to it.
^At least I don’t have to pay for it?
^I know it looks bad, but… …No, I have nothing, actually.
^If you want, we could go somewhere, the two of us. You could crash at my place for a few nights after.

^Sorry. Sounds nice, but I’m all out of vacation hours. I’d rather restock the shelves fast, so I can go back to bed. If you’re not buying, I… think it’s best for you to leave. My boss isn’t friendly to people without money to spend.
^This would be harder than you’d initially assumed. The offer wasn’t even entirely to ask her out.
^Her living situation, if you’re willing to stretch that to include a bag on a convenience store floor, is so absurd. Yet she shot down a chance to not break her spine for a night.
^You’d need to take this slow, ease her nerves.

Good: ^So much for easing her nerves. She frantically scans the room, though it’s completely empty except for the two of you. As if it's haunted with ghosts only she could see.
^Her panic fades however, when met with boxes upon boxes of products, unopened and unsorted. Stress falls to exhaustion, and with it, resignation.
^Okay…, if you’re offering, then… Maybe more sleep would be good for me.
Bad: ^You put a chocolate bar on the register. It moves down painfully slowly. You have never before in your life seen somebody eye a candy bar with such despair on their face. It inches closer to her. This is torture for your concsience.
^You can’t imagine how much worse it is for the clown. She picks it up like it was fifty times its weight, her gaze equally as heavy.
^How could you do this to her. A single beep rings out. Remy winces at the noise. This is your fault.
^Her voice shook. This was perhaps the worst decision you’ve ever made. Tapping your card was only a confirmation of your sins.
Scene2: ^Your plan for the night hadn’t included unpacking a near sisyphean amount of cardboard. You’d lost track of time, and there was no clock or window to judge from.

^Though it must be past midnight. Yet, the cardboard boxes seemed endless. If forced to do this repeatedly, with only the faint buzzing of freezers and ceiling lights in your ears, you might go insane.
^Exactly how long does it usually take her?

s: ^We need to be faster. I'm tired.

Bad2: ^Sorry, I’m being slow. I’m terrible at this. I’m actually kind of useless. You should just leave. I can do this by myself, really, you can lea-
^You make the decision to interrupt before she completely ruins her own self-esteem.
Good2: ^How often do you need to do this?
^And how are you not deranged yet because of it?
^I don’t think I kept track? I tried bringing it up to my boss once-
^Her voice lowered to a near whisper, and she looked over her shoulder before turning back to her cardboard abyss.
^but she said something about “building character”, and “being a team player”. And it’s not like I can prove her wrong.
^You keep talking about your boss. What about you?
^The question seemed to freeze her, stopping dead in her tracks.
Bad3: ^I, uh… Haven’t thought about it? I haven’t talked to someone who isn’t a co-clown or customer in… Huh. I can’t remember.
^Okay, maybe reassess your priorities. This case seems… unique.
Good3: ^If she was just shocked to be asked, or genuinely needed a few moments to remember her own name, you didn’t know. Both were concerning.
^She said it like the sounds were foreign to her.
^For the first time this evening, something resembling a smile appeared on Remy’s face.
^Time passes, while the boxes grow emptier and the shelves full. It even looked like the end might be near.
^While Remy at first glance was best described as… something like a shaken mouse turned unwilling paranormal investigator, you honestly were impressed by her.
^Doing this amount of labour, without losing her mind entirely, wasn’t to be sneezed at.
^And this amount of gatekeeping is absurd, women have always been part of game history.
^But the online landscapes are so toxic, which means less women participating, leading to invisibility again.
^I’d know, I’ve been in multiple tournaments. I even won a lot of them! But the things you hear in online matches… I don’t know where kids learn those words.
^She’d been going on like this for ages. Not that her engagement bothered you, quite the opposite. There was a spark to her, which you found charmingly contagious.
^…I miss writing my master’s degree. Actually- I just miss caring…
^Jesus. Maybe your first date should be therapy?
^Why is this place actually the worst.
^Remy: It’s not, really! Maybe top ten, but not the worst. My mom tells me she had it just as bad.
^Maybe you should bring her mom to therapy, too.
^I have not seen a single window in this building. I think that’s illegal. Did your mom have a fire escape route?
^Wouldn’t she understand, then? If you asked to stay home for a while?
^Remy shot you a glance like you’d just suggested murder.
^I- I… can’t do that! I told you, I’m out of vacation hours…
^Remy’s voice trailed off. You couldn’t help but feel like you’d messed up, after she’d been so passionate.
^She didn’t even speak anymore, disappearing into her repetitive restocking. Her  shift in tone caught you off-guard, joining you to the silent repetition.
^You didn’t want to set off her nerves again, so you used the space to carefully consider your next words.
^You couldn’t drag her out of here, she had to leave with you of her free will. Anything else would be a strange thing to do.
^Unlike all the normal things you do. Like breaking into circuses.
^You reached for another pack of sanitary pads to stock. An electric current shot through you when you touched skin instead.
^Remy squeaked, but didn’t move her hand. So there you were, hand on hand, on a pack of pads.
^You locked eyes. Faint buzz of lights, knees on cold tiled floor, holding the same menstrual product… It was not how you’d predicted your clown romantics to go.
^It was maybe not an inherently romantic setting, but the blush of Remy’s cheeks proved it could be. This was the first time you’d ever call kneeling on a dirty convenience store floor intimate.
Bad4: ^Thanks…? It’s mandatory… There’s a matching pyjama set. I’m not allowed to sleep without it.
^Damn it. You complimented the company that deprives her of sleep. Good going. You should find something else to compliment.
Good4: ^You feel incredibly good about this compliment. And as they say, ignorance is bliss.
^But maybe you and Remy are a match made in heaven, because she scrambled to recollect herself. Your luck should be studied.
^If she wanted to say something, she was interrupted.
^The sound of a sliding door sent her into high alert, craning her neck to look towards the entrance.
^You decide Remy’s genuine panic is reason enough to sprint behind the shelf you’d been stocking.
^Not the greatest hiding place, but out of sight from the entrance. It would have to do.
^The sound of approaching footsteps echoed unnaturally loud.
